Description: Lead model of a ribbed transport amphora: hollow, cylindrical neck and flared mouth with two looped strap handles either side, the ribbed body has a sharp carination and square cross-section tapering to the base; part broken (lost). Probably a votive model of an amphora. The amphora form seems to be a Roman type made in Egypt during the Roman Imperial or early Byzantine periods. Alternatively possibly a miniature sheath (?) or rhyton (?)
Curator's comments: Probably a votive model of an Egyptian amphora of teh roman Period. The ribbed form with looped handles and sharp carrination is a feature of AE3 (2nd to 5th century AD) and LRA7 (4th to 8th century AD) variants produced in Egypt. Two lead votive amphora models in the British Museum were both found in Egypt (1881,0614.110; 1964,0107.3), although these are of other forms.
